Trustie and welbeloved wee greate yo
w
well. Yo
w
shall understand that heare hath been, three Capteins w
ch
hearetofore have
s
rved in Camphire named
Jois vanden Eind
Carselis Palant
, and
Pierre de Costere
, whoe have
informed us that notw
th
standinge theie have by the space
of xviij
tie
yeares or theareabout
s
rved as Capteines, and
borne Armies under the
Prince of Orenge
,
o

o
tries

late yeares theie

rved w
th

n

, and for that when

, was Gouverno

y
as lefully

he might doo
they thought he might do
not to depart w
th
theire Companies owt of the said towne, w
ch
he did order
for the savetie of the
same
said towne

o
Ennemy.
yet ne
v
theless
uppon that pretext, and uppon su
m

of their goodwill towardes
us and
o

rvice, theie weare by

n

s
rvice
refused to be c
o

it appeared reproved for

o
r

r
theare, that wee had
great cause to mislike
the
such
unkind proceading
of the
sayd States against them, havinge noe other matter wherw
th
theie might be charged, but that upp
o
n

t
of the Erle of Leicester that was Gouverno

G
n
all of
all the Provinces, theie did
promise

to be

rviceable to us, not thearebie having anie mea-
ning either on o
r
part to drawe them from
e
s
rvice
of the publique Cawse of the Cuntrie, neither did
theie refuse to doe
s
rvice
in
for

as [.] anie Comm
o
n Ennemey:
and upp
o
n thes Consi
derations
the states semed well c
o
tent at our moti
o
for ther favor wh
r
uppn
the[.]
followed an Accord by certaine Articles
betwixt the Comte Maurice, and the States on the one
tie, and the said Capteines on the other, by w
ch
the
Comte Ma
sayd Capteines weare restored, as yt appeareth
by the Articles of the Accord to the favor of the States &
the Comte Maurice, and to theire places of
s
rvice, with
remission or rather oblivon of all thing
that had passed
to have moved offence, whearew
th
wee fownd o
r
selfe vearie well satisfied and accepted the same
fol.94r
thankefullie
on
for
the sayd Capteines behalf and theire
Companies: But notw
th
standing this Accord the
Capteines doe
now
informe us, that contrarie to the same, &
to the promise of the sayd Comte Maurice under his
hand writing,
e sayd Capteines are
by
e sayd stat
and Cont
depreved of
theire Companies, and theire paim
t
uppon theire
Accompt
refused; w
ch
being trewe, wee have great
Cawse to thinke o
r
selves from being towched in reputac
o
n:
And therefore wee knowing anie further matter wheare-
uppon to Judge, but by the informac
o
n of thes Capteines.
Wee have grawnted
to
them
[.] declare
t
we will cause
the state of their
Cawses
to be declared
to the States generall, and to require a redresse
therof. And for this purpose wee doe by this p
n
t
will and require yowe to take all such informac
o
ns
as the sayd Capteines bringing thes o
r
l
re
s unto yowe
shall geve yowe,
and make
wherby yow may se
the grownd of therin Com-
plaint thus made unto us,
to be
apparantly
unto yowe

, And
afterwardes, w
th
as Convenient sped as yowe maye
yowe shall
in our name exp
r
ssly

yo

o
n, as recommended from us, and move

e articles

r
for
will wishe them to have
more
[.]
regard
therof
than
of any
ticuler proffitt, or other displesure
toward
the sayd Capteines, having been men of good
s
rvice
against whome the worst theie
can
cold
alledge
is
was
that they by
Commaundm
t
of theire owne Generall the Erle of Leicester
did as all honest Capteines owght to have done, promise
to
either by othe or otherwise
to kepe
t
town saffe and also
to
s
rve us, to whome the whole
Cuntrie was committed in protecc
o
n, so as whatsoever might
be construed to be
s
rviceable to us,
[c.]
ought not
by anie reason be
compted but profitable
also
to the whole Cuntrie, and to the states
generall: and so yo
w
maie affirme, that wee doe precisely
accept the
s
rvices of all persons that
is
ar
or can be done
to us in the Cuntries, owght to be in reason adjudged to be
to the
s
rvice and Benefitt of the whole estate of thes
Provinc
being in o
r
protecc
o
n: for if anie other Construcc
o
be
made against anie that have offred or shall offer to
s
rve us
thear,
whylest we have
e
tecti
o
of those c
o
ntres,
wee shall have Cawse to thinke all o
r
fauc
es
&
charge bestowed uppon them to be ungratefullye received
by them./.
